name: Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT)
summary: Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT) is an evidence-based treatment designed to help children, adolescents, and their families overcome the negative effects of traumatic experiences.
description: Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT) is a structured, short-term therapeutic approach that integrates trauma-sensitive interventions with cognitive-behavioral, family, and humanistic principles. It is primarily used for children and adolescents who have experienced trauma, including abuse, violence, or disasters, and who are experiencing symptoms of PTSD, depression, or anxiety. TF-CBT involves both the child and their caregivers, with a focus on psychoeducation, coping skills, trauma narrative development, and gradual exposure to traumatic memories. The approach also emphasizes family involvement to support recovery and improve communication.

specialty_areas: Trauma and grief in children and adolescents

off_label_uses: Complex trauma in adolescents and adults
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe, though temporary distress may increase during trauma narrative work.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Strong evidence base with multiple randomized controlled trials
clinical_metadata.research_support: Supported by over 25 randomized controlled trials demonstrating effectiveness in reducing PTSD, depression, and anxiety in traumatized youth.

sections.text: TF-CBT works by combining cognitive-behavioral strategies with trauma-sensitive techniques. It helps children and adolescents process traumatic memories, correct distorted beliefs, and develop healthier coping skills. Family involvement strengthens support systems and improves communication, while gradual exposure to traumatic content reduces avoidance and distress.

sections.preparation: Assessment of trauma history, symptom severity, and caregiver involvement.
procedure: Psychoeducation about trauma and its effects
Skill-building in relaxation, affect regulation, and cognitive coping
Gradual development and processing of a trauma narrative
In vivo mastery of trauma reminders
Conjoint child-caregiver sessions to share trauma narratives and build communication

sections.pre_session: Review coping skills and symptom check-in
sections.treatment_phase: Skill practice, trauma narrative development, and caregiver engagement
sections.post_session: Homework assignments and reinforcement of safety skills

common: Increased anxiety during trauma narrative work
rare: Session dropout due to distress or avoidance

ideal_candidates: Children and adolescents with PTSD symptoms
Youth with trauma-related depression or anxiety
Families willing to participate in therapy
screening_required: Standardized trauma and PTSD symptom measures

practitioner: Mental health professionals with TF-CBT training

studies: Cohen, J. A., Mannarino, A. P., & Deblinger, E. (2006). Treating trauma and traumatic grief in children and adolescents.
Silverman, W. K., et al. (2008). Evidence-based psychosocial treatments for children and adolescents exposed to traumatic events.
sections.limitations: Less studied in adults and in culturally diverse populations; requires caregiver involvement for best outcomes.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Moderate; 12–20 sessions make it relatively cost-effective compared to long-term treatments
sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered under child and adolescent mental health services
sections.cost_effectiveness: Highly cost-effective given strong evidence base and relatively short treatment duration

lifestyle_recommendations: Encouragement of social support and positive activities

sections.children: Primary target group; TF-CBT is highly effective in children ages 3–18.
sections.adolescents: Effective for adolescents with PTSD or trauma-related symptoms.
sections.cultural: Requires cultural adaptation for diverse populations; family values and beliefs should be integrated.

items: TF-CBT is considered the gold standard treatment for childhood trauma-related PTSD.
Caregiver participation significantly improves treatment outcomes.
Trauma narrative work should be paced carefully to avoid overwhelming the child.

items.label: Cohen, J. A., Mannarino, A. P., & Deblinger, E. (2006). Treating trauma and traumatic grief in children and adolescents.
Silverman, W. K., et al. (2008). Evidence-based psychosocial treatments for children and adolescents exposed to traumatic events.

seo.title: Trauma-Focused CBT (TF-CBT) | Evidence-Based Therapy for Childhood Trauma and PTSD
seo.description: Trauma-Focused Cognitive Behavioral Therapy (TF-CBT) is a short-term, evidence-based treatment for children and adolescents with trauma and PTSD. It integrates coping skills, trauma processing, and family involvement for lasting recovery.
